meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>ground</radical>, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found <kanji>both</kanji> a <radical>mountain</radical> and a <radical>head</radical>, two strange things to find underground.
meaning_hint: You'll want to focus on the part where you find <kanji>both</kanji>, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so well finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.
reading_mnemonic: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat floating off in the distance.
reading_hint: Also think... "What's that row boat doing here?" But, it's your only hope, so you have to focus on it really hard.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>death</radical> and the kanji <kanji>death</kanji> are the same.
meaning_hint: This thing is deceased. It ain't alive anymore.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>death</kanji> will be because of a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) accident. Oh, you didn't know? You're going to be hit by a giant bowling ball and crushed flat.
reading_hint: You didn't want to know what would cause your death, you say? Well that's a shame. I guess you could try to avoid bowling from now on, but that won't do any good. Mark my words, your death will be bowling-related.

meaning_mnemonic: There is a <radical>lid</radical> covering all the <radical>mouth</radical>s that are too <radical>small</radical> to feed themselves, forming the <kanji>capital</kanji>. All of the small mouths come together and create a place where everyone can support each other.
meaning_hint: Picture the capital of your country. How many mouths have come together to support each other there? A thousand? A million? More?!
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading きょう we use the Japanese city, Kyoto, which is spelled <reading>きょう</reading>と. It was once the capital of Japan! It was soooo full of mouths that came together that it was the capital for a long, long time.
reading_hint: When you think of the capital, think of きょうと!

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Kings</radical> with <radical>hats</radical>. Did you know that <kanji>all</kanji> kings wear hats?
meaning_hint: Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what, every single one of them (aka <kanji>all</kanji> of them) wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, and normal hats. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they all are wearing them.
reading_mnemonic: But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not <kanji>all</kanji> of them have hats after all. The last one you come to does not have a hat. He is the king of <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) Buddhism. He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby.
reading_hint: To add to this story and make it more memorable, you can imagine the other kings getting upset, saying things like "<kanji>All</kanji> kings must wear hats! You are no king!" The king of <reading>Zen</reading> Buddhism just ignores them and begins to meditate.

meaning_mnemonic:
There are some <radical>horns</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>knife</radical> in <kanji>front</kanji> of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason.

This kanji means <kanji>before</kanji> too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all.
meaning_hint: Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run. Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.
reading_mnemonic: You're going crazy with these things in <kanji>front</kanji> of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん) master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!
reading_hint: Go ahead and do some Zen Buddhist meditation. Maybe it'll help you to remember this kanji's reading better (and calm your mind so you're ready for the next kanji!).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> with a <radical>spoon</radical> is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great <kanji>change</kanji> in the world.
meaning_hint: Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally <kanji>change</kanji> everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can do with such a blunt, small device!
reading_mnemonic: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, <kanji>changing</kanji> it into a <reading>car</reading> (か).
reading_hint: Of course, doing something like this is utterly amazing. Feel amazed in your imagination, because if you don't, then it'll be hard to remember the reading for this kanji. If you are amazed, you'll know that spoons going to cars = the reading is か, so make sure you take the time to be amazed.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>cross</radical> you're holding above your <radical>head</radical> to keep your <radical>horns</radical> <radical>dry</radical> keeps pulling you <kanji>south</kanji>. Probably because it's warmer in the south of Japan, so it's easier to keep things dry.
meaning_hint: Look down and see the compass pointing south and feel the cross pulling you in that direction.
reading_mnemonic: You finally make it down <kanji>south</kanji>, and it is dry, but you're really hungry. When you try to find southern food you realize every single store is only selling <reading>naan</reading> (なん).
reading_hint: Imagine being in the south and taking big bites of naan. It tastes good, but now your mouth is dry just like your horns. Too dry...

meaning_mnemonic: There's an <radical>ear</radical> just sitting on a <radical>stool</radical>. Nobody's watching, so, you <kanji>take</kanji> it.
meaning_hint: Feel the rush of stealing something (even though it's a weird something, admittedly). Start walking away quickly. You don't want to get caught!
reading_mnemonic: You're the kind of person who likes <vocabulary>to take</vocabulary> things. "What things?" you ask. Little <reading>toe</reading>s (と). Because that isn't creepy.
reading_hint: When someone asks you "Do you like to take little toes?" your answer is always "Toetally."

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>drop</radical> hits your <radical>mustache</radical>. Where did it come from? "Ah, it came from <kanji>yonder</kanji>," you say, <kanji>facing</kanji> that way.
meaning_hint: Yonder is a bit of a weird word, but it fits the meaning of this kanji quite well. You'll have to trust me that it's more useful in Japanese than it is in English. When you imagine through this mnemonic, make sure the drop comes from the side and hits you in the mustache with quite a bit of force. That means it came from a far distance thus making you look over "yonder."
reading_mnemonic: Who shot this drop at you from <kanji>yonder</kanji>? You look over yonder, and see a figure. It is <reading>こう</reading>いち.
reading_hint:
"Who is that over yonder!" you yell.
"It is I, (こういち)," he yells back. "I shot at you over yonder because you weren't doing your kanji reviews often enough and you're taking up space on our database."
"But I'm paying you!"
"Oh, that's true. Well, I'm going to walk over yonder and leave you alone, then."

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>mouth</radical> of the <radical>king</radical> extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his <kanji>country</kanji>, give or take a few <radical>drop</radical>s.
meaning_hint: Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.
reading_mnemonic: Turns out the king of this <kanji>country</kanji> loves drinking <reading>Coke</reading> (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.
reading_hint: Would you drink that much soda for breakfast? Now this king says he wants to pass a law requiring everyone in the country to drink nothing but Coke! That's crazy!

meaning_mnemonic:
A <radical>dirt</radical> <radical>alligator</radical> lives in the <kanji>earth</kanji>, not the water. They can swim through the earth itself! Which is pretty scary.

You can think of this word as <kanji>ground</kanji> too, because that's kind of what earth is made of.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the earth moving as a dirt alligator rises out from the ground. You should run.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to keep this dirt alligator from dragging you under the <kanji>earth</kanji> and eating you is to feed it <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). That way it won't lead you to a horrific death under the earth by dragging you under and spinning you around until you eat dirt (literally).
reading_hint: If you ever see someone throwing cheese on the ground, now you know why. They aren't crazy, they're saving us humans from what's lurking under the earth.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> is wearing a <radical>lid</radical> and is standing outside in <radical>winter</radical>. Plus it's raining and she's covered in <radical>drop</radical>s of water. On top of all this, it's <kanji>night</kanji>.
meaning_hint: If it helps, you can come up with a reason why she's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is she wearing a lid on her head? Probably because she's protecting her people from something that comes at night.
reading_mnemonic: Question is, what is she protecting them from during the <kanji>night</kanji>? Turns out, it's the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や) baseball team. They're out for blood, and only the leader can protect us.
reading_hint: Imagine the Yankees stomping towards the leader, baseball bats in hand, blood on their faces. They're here to eat, and nobody will stop them. Feel the fear of their approach. Will you survive another night with them on the prowl?

meaning_mnemonic: Who's that <radical>woman</radical> pretending to be a <radical>jet</radical>? That's my <kanji>younger sister</kanji>. *Sigh*
meaning_hint: Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>younger sister</kanji> is giving some <reading>mi</reading>ce (まい) a ride on her back like a jet.
reading_hint: Ew, gross. Your younger sister is such a weirdo! Why does she have mice on her back while pretending to be a jet?

meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>woman</radical> in this <radical>city</radical> is your <kanji>older sister</kanji>. She's the only woman surrounded by a bunch of men, but she's following her dreams in the big city.
meaning_hint: You want to go to the city someday, but you're not old enough yet, like your older sister is.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>older sister</kanji> may have moved to the city, but she kept her pet <reading>shee</reading>p (し) with her. Now the only woman in the city is your older sister, and the only sheep is her pet.
reading_hint: Picture your older sister and her sheep walking through the city. Everyone turns to stare at them, because they're the only ones of their kind.

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>roof</radical> over her head, a <radical>woman</radical> can <kanji>relax</kanji>. She doesn't have to worry about rain or snow or finding a place to sleep. The roof also happened to be super <kanji>cheap</kanji>, so she can even relax about her finances.
meaning_hint: Picture the super relaxed woman lounging under her cheap but sturdy roof. Ah, she doesn't have a care in the world!
reading_mnemonic: As she <kanji>relax</kanji>es, she pulls out the <kanji>cheap</kanji>est, most relaxing food in the world: <reading>an</reading>chovies (あん).
reading_hint: Think about it: anchovies cost next to nothing, they come in cans, you don't have to cook them or cut them up. You just munch them down. There's nothing more cheap and relaxing than eating anchovies under your own roof.

meaning_mnemonic: On the <radical>dirt</radical> you've made a <radical>roof</radical> over the <radical>ground</radical> where you can be in <radical>private</radical>. This is your <kanji>room</kanji>! That's really all a room is, you know? A covered, private place where you can have some time to yourself.
meaning_hint: Imagine the room you live in now. Take away all the stuff and you're left with a roof and the dirt on the ground. It's your own little private place.
reading_mnemonic: The only problem with your <kanji>room</kanji> is that you can't always be alone. Because of your dad's <reading>shih tzu</reading> (しつ). The shih tzu likes to come into your room and pee everywhere. Ruining your privacy completely.
reading_hint: Imagine watching the little shih tzu come into your room and lift its leg to all your things. This isn't fair. The shih tzu has its own room to pee in. Why does it have to ruin yours?

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>house</radical> radical makes up the <kanji>house</kanji> kanji! Pretty easy. This kanji is also used to mean <kanji>home</kanji>, so try to remember that too.
meaning_hint: I guess not all houses are homes, and not all homes are houses. But there's a pretty big overlap, right? And in most situations, this kanji's got you covered.
reading_mnemonic: What do you do in your <kanji>house</kanji>? You <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>e</reading>ggs (いえ), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your <kanji>home</kanji>!
reading_hint: Imagine all the eggs you've got in your house. Whole fridgefuls! It's not a normal house, but that's okay. If you couldn't eat eggs, it wouldn't feel like home.

meaning_mnemonic: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. They're basically three <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical> <radical>drop</radical>s in the large <radical>river</radical> that is the Pacific Ocean. These are Japan's <kanji>states</kanji> or <kanji>province</kanji>s.
meaning_hint: Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!
reading_mnemonic: Each <kanji>state</kanji> has its own <reading>shoe</reading> (しゅう) to represent it. The bottom of each shoe is the shape of the state, so when you step it leaves a state-shaped imprint in the ground.
reading_hint: The state shoes also have things like the state birds, state flowers, and state fish printed on each of them. They're quite collectable, you should buy a pair for your favorite state!

meaning_mnemonic: A long time ago, someone put up a <radical>canopy</radical> over their <radical>fortune</radical> telling booth and created the first <kanji>shop</kanji>. This <kanji>store</kanji> was fortune-based, but since then lots of different stores have popped up!
meaning_hint: Picture the very first store in history. A fortune teller decided enough was enough, they should be in some kind of structure where it's safe, official looking, and more permanent.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>shop</kanji> quickly turned into <reading>ten</reading> (てん) shops! It was a good idea, after all, so all of the other people selling goods and services decided to copy it and create their own shops. The next day there were ten more.
reading_hint: Picture ten shops, all made up of someone selling something under a canopy. The first one is the fortune teller, but the nine others are whatever you want them to be!

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>loiter</radical> around to <radical>poop</radical> in <radical>winter</radical> you never know what could be happening <kanji>behind</kanji> you. <kanji>After</kanji> you're done you could turn <kanji>back</kanji> to see something really crazy that you missed because you took so long to poop in the cold.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to loiter while you poop in the winter. You're just trying to take your time as you squat over the snow, but soon you hear things behind you.
reading_mnemonic: You finally look <kanji>behind</kanji> you and see <reading>Go</reading>dzilla (ご) and a giant <reading>こう</reading>いち having a violent battle <kanji>back</kanji> there!
reading_hint: Godzilla and こういち were going at it behind you the entire time you were just lazily taking a poop in the snow?! Ahh, that's so embarrassing! And also dangerous, they could have crushed you! You should look behind you more.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>rice paddy</radical> you find a <radical>heart</radical> and it makes you <kanji>think</kanji>. You think a lot of <kanji>thought</kanji>s like, "Whose heart is this? Why is it in a rice paddy? Why am I thinking out loud?"
meaning_hint: Think, think, think. Think about this rice paddy heart.
reading_mnemonic: As you are <kanji>think</kanji>ing these <kanji>thought</kanji>s, you spot someone on the edge of the rice field. He really reminds you of someone. But who? That's it! He reminds you of that bartender on The Simpsons. What's his name? You think some more. What is it? <reading>Oh! Moe</reading> (おも) is his name!
reading_hint: If you don't know Moe from the Simpsons use a different Moe, perhaps the one from the Three Stooges? You should be able to come up with one. Think really hard about the Moe you know best and imagine them standing watching you from the edge of the rice field.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> AND the <radical>moon</radical> are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly <kanji>bright</kanji> outside.
meaning_hint: Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.
reading_mnemonic: When do things start to get <kanji>bright</kanji> outside? I'd say when things start getting sunny, and that is the month of <reading>May</reading> (めい). If you live in the Southern Hemisphere, it's bright in May because of all the snow, or because that's when all the streetlights come on.
reading_hint: Depending on where you live, you might want to come up with a different reason for all that brightness in May. Perhaps it's because of Mother's Day, since we all know how brightly mothers shine. The important thing is to remember just how bright the month of May is, for whatever reason!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> that gives <radical>life</radical> is our very own <kanji>star</kanji> (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
meaning_hint: Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky and there are billions of them. I hope you don't feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>star</kanji> (the sun) and all of the others are yours to protect with your trusty <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい). If you could protect your land from the West, then you can certainly defend the stars too!
reading_hint: Now you're soaring through between the stars, swinging your saber through the silence of space, and... wait. No that was a dream. You roll over and pat your saber. The two of you are ready just in case the stars need your help.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Twenty</radical> <radical>mouths</radical> are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful <kanji>music</kanji> together.
meaning_hint: Listen to the twenty mouths. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Also note that this kanji also means "bend." Imagine the music coming out at you <kanji>bend</kanji>ing all around in strange shapes through the air.
reading_mnemonic: The twenty mouths make so much <kanji>music</kanji> that they literally <reading>cloak you</reading> (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music.
reading_hint: Imagine how you feel as they cloak you with music. Feel the music all around you, enveloping you. Become the music itself.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>narwhal</radical> and a <radical>moon</radical> is all you <kanji>have</kanji>. Imagine one of each under your arms.
meaning_hint: You don't have anything else. This is it. All you have.
reading_mnemonic: Everything you <kanji>have</kanji> (except the narwhal and the moon) were taken from you by a roving gang of <reading>you</reading>ths (ゆう).
reading_hint: They came and took your things. Now they have all your stuff, and you only have the moon and a narwhal. You don't have much anymore, but at least you have these things still.

meaning_mnemonic: Behind that <radical>tree</radical> the <radical>sun</radical> is rising in the <kanji>east</kanji>. The sun always rises in the east, so if you head that way, past the tree, you'll be going east too.
meaning_hint: Picture the sun behind the tree, don't picture the sun alone, you'll burn your eyes. It's slowly coming up behind it. Now think: where does the sun rise? In the east!
reading_mnemonic: You walk <kanji>east</kanji> for a few hours until you finally come to a city. It's <reading>とう</reading>きょう. Oh! とうきょう is in the east. I get it now!
reading_hint: When you think about East Japan think about とうきょう. And if you're bad at geography, just look at a map for a while. Or, stand outside in the morning, watch the sun rise behind the trees, and point that way. That's east, it's where とうきょう is!

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>stop</radical> at a <radical>small</radical> <radical>slide</radical>. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were <kanji>walk</kanji>ing.
meaning_hint: Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say "keep walking, friend."
reading_mnemonic: So, you're <kanji>walk</kanji>ing around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.
reading_hint: Of course, imagine the pain of your face. Did your nose break? After bringing yourself together, look down at what hit you. It's a hoe! How did you manage to step on just the right spot to flip it up on you like that? Examine the hoe. Pay close attention to it. Whose hoe is this? etc.

meaning_mnemonic: If the <radical>yakuza</radical> hands you a <radical>spoon</radical>, <kanji>death</kanji> is coming for you. It's the death spoon, a sign that the yakuza is coming to cause your death.
meaning_hint: This spoon isn't for pudding, it's for death!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Death</kanji> comes in the form of a <reading>shee</reading>p (し). The death sheep works for the yakuza, and kills anyone who has their spoon.
reading_hint: Picture the death sheep. He looks like a black shadow, and he has a scar on his face. He's holding a bunch of spoons, from all the other people the yakuza marked for death!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> of <radical>tongue</radical>s is coming at you. As it washes over you, you feel each individual tongue moving around on your body, licking you. They make you feel so... <kanji>lively</kanji>!
meaning_hint: Your entire body wakes up, you feel so lively! The tongues are making you more aware of yourself and your surroundings than you've ever been. You want to dance, you want to sing, you want to live your life.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>lively</kanji> feeling isn't just happening to you, the tongue tsunami is licking it into all of the <reading>cats</reading> (かつ) in your neighborhood too!
reading_hint: You and the cats are running around playing together, because you can't seem to get the lively feelings to stop. You have to get the energy out, but the cats have sharp claws and they're scratching you.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, so you point your <radical>gun</radical> out the <radical>window</radical> at it. "You better turn back, <kanji>sea</kanji>, or I'll shoot!"
meaning_hint: You'll have to think of the "sea" as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the "sea," not the "tsunami." It's like aiming for the head of a zombie and not the arms or legs.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sea</kanji> decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way. You hop in your <reading>kay</reading>ak (かい) and chase after it with your gun, to make sure it actually returns to the sea and doesn't just drown someone else.
reading_hint: Imagine paddling in your kayak, your gun still in one hand, as you chase the sea back to its home.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>fortune</radical> <radical>boil</radical>s down to a single <kanji>point</kanji> in time. One point in time determines how the rest of your future will go.
meaning_hint: Imagine actually going somewhere to get your fortune told and watching a big boiling pot of goo. As it boils, it melts down to a single point at the very bottom. Where this point is determines your future.
reading_mnemonic: As you stare at the <kanji>point</kanji>, you watch in awe as it moves to the <reading>ten</reading> (てん) spot in a long series of numbers.
reading_hint: Is the ten spot good? Are you going to live a long life or does this point mean you're only going to live ten more years?! Ahh!

meaning_mnemonic: You accidentally stab your <radical>cross</radical> into the <radical>eye</radical> of a <radical>lion</radical>. This is a terrible thing you did and you need to <kanji>fix</kanji> it right now. I'll be <kanji>direct</kanji> with you, this is something you have to fix on your own.
meaning_hint: How will you fix this mistake though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything.
reading_mnemonic: As you try to <kanji>fix</kanji> the lion's eye, it starts to <reading>choke</reading> (ちょく) and make what can only be described as a <reading>jiki</reading>jiki sound (じき). Through its choking jikijiki sounds, it coughs up a gear. Wait. Is this a machine lion?
reading_hint: You're relieved! You don't know how to fix a choking, eye-stabbed lion, but you can absolutely fix a ROBOTIC one. Robots are fixable.

meaning_mnemonic: Just before saying something important, you take an <radical>arrow</radical> to the <radical>mouth</radical> which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you <kanji>know</kanji> with someone else.
meaning_hint: Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading ち we use the word "cheese."

One of the things you <kanji>know</kanji> is actually very strange but very important. The president's <reading>chee</reading>se (ち) has been poisoned and only you know. If you could just say something then maybe you could save her... but... you have an arrow in your mouth.
reading_hint: Try saying the words "cheese" with an arrow in your mouth. What would that sound like? Go ahead and pretend out loud.

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <radical>private</radical> <radical>grain</radical>s are meant to stay <kanji>private</kanji>! You shouldn't be sharing them with the whole town, they're just for you.

This kanji also means <kanji>I</kanji>. Why? Because what's more private than you? I mean, I! Basically, some things are only the business of you (I) and those things should be private.
meaning_hint: Look at your private grains. Who are those for? Why, they're for I!
reading_mnemonic: You're getting into the zone, thinking about yourself (<kanji>I</kanji>) and how much you love having things that are <kanji>private</kanji> and just yours, when you realize there is a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) in this grain bag. And it's eating all of your (I's) private grains. No!
reading_hint: The moral of the story is: don't let a sheep sneak into your private stash of things just for you (I). I'm sure this is a metaphor for something important...

meaning_mnemonic: You scoop some <radical>grain</radical>s into a <radical>ladle</radical> to do <kanji>science</kanji>. You're doing experiments on these grains in your science <kanji>course</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine carefully ladling grains into different piles so you can do science experiments on them. This course is going to make you an expert. You'll be the best in this department!
reading_mnemonic: Using your <kanji>science</kanji> skills, the right temperatures and measurements, you manage to get these grains to grow into a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). This is the science <kanji>department</kanji>'s special car now!
reading_hint: From your science meddling, these grains grow huge, red, and sprout sports cars when they're ripe. This is the true power of science!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sheep</radical> radical and the <kanji>sheep</kanji> kanji are the same in looks as well in meaning.
meaning_hint: You are no sheep—you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!
reading_mnemonic: To remember よう, we use the word "Yogurt." The <kanji>sheep</kanji> are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... because you stole their sheep's milk <reading>yo</reading>gurt (よう). Now you're running and crying and trying to eat the yogurt before the sheep catch up and stomp you down with their hooves.
reading_hint: Imagine the taste of this yogurt. You're scared and tired from running, but it tastes great!

meaning_mnemonic: You come across an <radical>angel</radical> wearing a <radical>hat</radical> that's covered in <radical>flowers</radical>. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make <kanji>tea</kanji> out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.
meaning_hint: How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*
reading_mnemonic: In your <kanji>tea</kanji> you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says "To <reading>Cha</reading>d (ちゃ), you'll make an awesome angel." Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel.
reading_hint: It gets kind of weird when you know their names... Usually you just make them into tea without knowing who they are (easier that way). This one... this one is Chad, and you remember it vividly, because now you feel kind of bad.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>blood</radical> radical and <kanji>blood</kanji> are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
meaning_hint: There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!
reading_mnemonic:
To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup!

The radical is technically <radical>blood</radical>, but you know that radical is just a drop (of blood) on a plate. So, you ask yourself... Is that really blood on the plate? Could it be? You decide to take a gamble and lick it off. When you taste it, it's definitely not blood. No, it's <reading>ketsup</reading> (けつ).
reading_hint: Feel the relief that you didn't just lick up someone's blood. Taste the ketsup taste, too. It's pretty good. Not quite ketchup, but not quite catsup. Yum!

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>long</radical> radical and the <kanji>long</kanji> kanji are the same! 

This kanji also means <kanji>leader</kanji>, because the longer a person is, the better a leader they'll be. Or maybe it was... the longer they've been somewhere? Whatever, longness = leaderness, you know?
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical long, you know the kanji long as well.
reading_mnemonic: You see a very <kanji>long</kanji> person. It's Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう), who has made herself long, like her street. "I made myself long so I can watch more of the street, my domain. I'm the <kanji>leader</kanji> of these streets. Watch yourself not-long person," says Mrs. Chou.
reading_hint: <kanji>Long</kanji> isn't an idea that's easy to imagine in any specific sense, but you can try some other things too, as long as it gets associated with Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading>. For the most part, when you see a kanji with the radical 長 the reading will be ちょう.

meaning_mnemonic: The radical for <radical>eat</radical> and the kanji for <kanji>eat</kanji> are the same! Lucky you.
meaning_hint: If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is <kanji>meal</kanji>. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know "eat" you should be able to remember "meal" as well.
reading_mnemonic: Thank goodness, you finally get to <kanji>eat</kanji> your <kanji>meal</kanji>. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a <reading>shock</reading> (しょく) from somewhere.
reading_hint: So, do you keep eating and keep getting shocked? Or do you not eat and continue to starve? What is worse? Obviously you're in one of the Saw movies, or something, too, so feel the fear. What will you choose? Life with shocks or death from hunger?

meaning_mnemonic: The radical <radical>neck</radical> and the kanji <kanji>neck</kanji> are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: The only thing you do with your <kanji>neck</kanji> is use it to swallow lots of <reading>coo</reading>l <reading>bea</reading>ns (くび). Mm mm. Feel those cool, cool beans sliding down your neck. You don't really taste them, but you know they're there.
reading_hint: Look at yourself in a mirror as the cool beans make their way down your neck. You can see them, like little ants marching all the way down to your tummy.
